This classical-revival style service is ornamented with rolled borders, cast medallions and duplicate etched leaf designs.

The design suggests a precision that was achieved through mass production, a trend that developed during this period.

82386.title: Finestra Table Lamp base
82386.title_notes: 10/16/2012 Per Linda Kinsey, Michael Graves Design Group: For the Denver show it was decided to change the name of the lamp to Finestra because Yamagiwa had only a fleeting relationship with the design.  The model was made for the client, Yamagiwa, but it was never produced.  Therefore, the name was changed to Finestra for the Denver US Design exhibition.  Finestra was chosen because the sides of the lamp recall the fenestration of a window.

23275.title: quilt (Grapes and Vines)
23275.credit_line: Webster Collection, Gift of Mrs. Gerrish Thurber
23275.medium_support: linen appliquéd on cotton and quilted
23275.provenance: Mrs. Gerrish Thurber, Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1979.
23275.inscription: Signed and dated, verso, corner: Marie D. Webster / 1914

extended_text.content:
Between 1911 and 1912, eight of Marie Webster’s quilts were featured in color in the Ladies’ Home Journal, one of the leading women’s periodicals of the time. Webster, a pioneer quiltmaker, designed all the original patterns for her quilts. In the 1920s and the 1930s these patterns were sold through her home business, the Practical Patchwork Company.

Marie Webster finished this quilt in time to include it in her 1915 landmark publication Quilts, Their Story and How to Make Them. It is executed in pastel shades, a Webster trademark. Approximately 800 grapes, leaves, narrow vines and tendrils were painstakingly appliquéd using minute stitches. This quilt, made up of four appliquéd squares, is a revival of the four-block set popular in the mid-nineteenth century. The addition of Webster’s innovation, the appliquéd sashing strips in the middle, sets this quilt apart from others. The scalloped outer border follows the long wavy vine pattern on the inner border.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

23275.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

29513.title: quilt (Daisies)
29513.credit_line: Webster Collection, Gift of Mrs. Gerrish Thurber
29513.medium_support: linen appliquéd on cotton and quilted
29513.provenance: Mrs. Gerrish Thurber, Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1979.
29513.inscription: Inscribed, dated, and signed, verso, corner: For / Ladies Home Journal / 1912 / Marie D. Webster

extended_text.content: “…teach the little one to tell the petals of the daisy- ‘loves me, loves me not’-and many happy moments will be spent in finding out whether the child or his mother loves the more.” (Marie Daugherty Webster in Ladies Home Journal, August 1912.) This quilt is signed and dated “For Ladies Home Journal, 1912. Marie D. Webster
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

5966.title: quilt (Morning Glory Wreath)
5966.credit_line: Webster Collection, Gift of Mrs. Gerrish Thurber
5966.medium_support: linen appliquéd on cotton and quilted
5966.provenance: Mrs. Gerrish Thurber, Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1979.

extended_text.content: “It must be ‘early to bed and early to rise’ for the child who would see the sweet morning glory in all its loveliness, as it must be found before all the dew is gone. Then, too, this delicate flower always curls up and goes to sleep before sunset.” (Marie Daugherty Webster in Ladies Home Journal, August 1912.) This quilt is signed and dated “For Ladies Home Journal", 1912. Marie D. Webster
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

5966.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

8524.title: quilt (Sunflower)
8524.credit_line: Webster Collection, Gift of Mrs. Gerrish Thurber
8524.medium_support: linen appliquéd on cotton and quilted
8524.provenance: Mrs. Gerrish Thurber, Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1979.

extended_text.content:
A strong advocate of the Arts and Crafts Movement, Marie Webster used quilting as an integral part of the overall design of each quilt, employing the process for more than just technical or decorative purposes. Sunflower, along with three other quilts appeared in the January 1912 issue of Ladies Home Journal. Webster’s fresh artistic ideas were expressed through the intricate stitchery of the spider webs in the central part of the quilt. She described it as follows:

“The Sunflower quilt shows a very realistic bold design of vivid coloring but well balanced in its relation to space. The border, too, is harmonious, suggesting a firm foundation for the stems. The quilting in the center is noticeable attractive in a design of spider webs, leaves and flowers.”
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

8524.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

24363.title: quilt (Bedtime)
24363.credit_line: Webster Collection, Gift of Mrs. Gerrish Thurber
24363.provenance: Mrs. Gerrish Thurber, Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1979.
24363.inscription: Signed, inscribed, and dated: Marie D. Webster. / Designed for Ladies Home Journal. / 1912

extended_text.content:
“The bedtime quilt, with its procession of night-clad children, will be excellent ‘company’ for a tot, to whom a story may be told of the things that slip near the little trees while the friendly stars keep watch.” (Marie D. Webster in Ladies Home Journal, 1912.)

This quilt is signed and dated “For Ladies Home Journal, 1912. Marie D. Webster

13279.title: Eli Lilly Family Quilt
13279.creation_notes: Created by the Lilly family, along with spouses and friends. But keep Creator as "Unknown" per Textile and Fashion Arts Curator Niloo Paydar, since we do not know exactly who participated in the making of the quilt.
13279.credit_line: Gift of Louise Emerson Francke, a great great granddaughter of Eli Lilly of Baltimore County, Maryland
13279.medium_support: cotton appliquéd, pieced, embroidered, and quilted
13279.provenance:
Louise Emerson Franke{1}, Maryland; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (1996).
{1} The great-great-granddaughter of Eli Lilly of Baltimore County, Maryland
13279.inscription:
Signed, near center of 20 squares, by friends and family of Eli Lilly:
Top row: Magdaline Emmart Balto. Co. / Caleb F. Lilly / Maria Johnson / Evan Lilly / Elizabeth Adeline Emmart  
Second row: Ann Emmart / [no inscription]  / Mary Ann Seymour / Emily Jane x Lilly . Balto. Co / [no inscription]
Third row: [no inscription] / Gustavus Lilly / [no inscription] / Amanda Barnett Balto. Co. / Edwin Lilly
Fourth row: Rachel Wolf Balto. Co. / Eli Lilly / Bell [or Bill] Barnett. Wheatland Balto. Co / Abel Seymour / Wm A. Disney /
Bottom row: A. Josephine Ridgley, Clay Hill Balto. Co.  / Mary Luth George / Minerva Ann Lilly / Madaleine Barnett / [no inscription]

extended_text.content:
Commemorative album quilts were popular in the United States between 1840 and 1860. These quilts were typically cooperative endeavors, made by a number of women. The finished work was presented to an honored recipient such as a teacher, minister, or other important community member. This beautiful quilt, however, belongs to a type sometimes referred to as a "death watch quilt." It was made in 1847, the year of his death, to honor Eli Lilly, grandfather of Colonel Eli Lilly, who in 1876 founded the Indianapolis pharmaceutical firm named for him. Twenty of the blocks were signed by the friends and family who gathered at Lilly's bedside during his final days, and his own signature appears in the block with the lyre.

The most elaborate album quilts came from Maryland's Baltimore County and are called Baltimore album quilts. In this accomplished example, a green-and-red-swag border frames floral blocks in vivid hues. Wreaths, floral sprays, cornucopias, and baskets-traditional album-quilt motifs-fill the central area. Elaborately drawn and expertly appliquéd patterns make this quilt a particularly successful instance of a timeless American art form.

[This] quilt was created by the Lilly family, along with spouses and friends, during the long months of 1847 [when] Eli Lilly lay ill.
-Louise Francke, 1996
extended_text.content_type: Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection (2005)
extended_text.title: Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection (2005)

extended_text.content:
When contemplating the future of the Lilly Quilt, I felt that Indianapolis might be its natural resting place because of the Eli Lilly Family. A strong secondary reason for placing the quilt in Indianapolis was climate. As I left New York City, I did not want to bring this wonderful piece of history to Florida’s neotropical environment. I am happy that it has found its natural home at the IMA.

-Louise E. Francke

Album quilts were very fashionable between 1840 and 1860. Album quilt blocks were made and signed by a number of women, and the quilt was presented to an honored recipient. This historically significant quilt was signed by friends and family of Eli Lilly (1780-1847) at his bedside during his final illness. He signed the block with the lyre, and his third child (father of Colonel Eli Lilly, who founded Eli Lilly and Company) signed the block above the lyre. Minerva Ann Lilly, the ninth child, signed the bottom block with the fruit basket. The donor, Mrs. Louise Emerson Francke, is her great-granddaughter.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

13279.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB:

45117.title: Horse Auction
45117.credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Cantor
45117.provenance: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Cantor; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1963.
45117.inscription: signed in pencil, L.R.: Boardman Robinson

extended_text.content:
Boardman Robinson came west in 1931 to assume the direction of the 10-year-old Broadmoor Art Academy and remained until 1947 through its transformation into the Colorado Springs Fine Arts Center.

For this lithograph, Robinson culled several figures from his large Works Progress Administration mural, “Horse Sale” finished in 1940 in the Englewood, Colorado post office.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

45117.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

23270.title: Comanche Portrait
23270.provenance: Purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1980.
23270.inscription: signed in pencil, below image, L.R.:  Chas. B. Wilson / Tsui va ni

extended_text.content:
This lithograph was created while Wilson was still a student at the Art Institute of Chicago.

It was a portrait of one of the few remaining pure-blooded Native Americans in Wilson’s native state of Oklahoma.

Wilson’s interest in the Native Americans led him to write a standard work on the Indian Tribes of Eastern Oklahoma.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

23270.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012
